title: PSA:  Juggernauts are not tanks.
body:
Tank:

Tanks are durable, front-line champions that help lock down enemies and start fights. They're usually found leading the charge, choosing the right times and situations to initiate aggression. Many tanks can also protect their more fragile teammates by stunning or pushing around dangerous foes and limiting their damage potential.

Juggernaut:

These heavy-duty champions boast powerful defenses in addition to tremendous natural resilience (or tankiness), and while entering a fight is particularly difficult for a juggernaut, actual combat heavily favors them once they are in range. Juggernauts tend to favor heavily defensive builds, though what few offensive items they purchase significantly enhance their already potent innate damage.

The wiki is your friend, learn to use it when defining the purpose of champions and clarifying strengths and weaknesses of champions.

In short:
Tanks lead the fight, engaging and locking down enemies for the team.
Juggernauts follow up on the engage and attempt to kill enemies

Please refrain from assuming that because a champion is durable it means they are a tank, juggernauts are not tanks.

The Pokemon community actually distinguishes between strong and bulky Pokemon and just bulky Pokemon, through "tank" and "wall" respectively. Granted, that's kinda the same problem as "tank" and "juggernaut," just with tank on the other side, but it's interesting to see how "tank" being the catch-all for bulky is not as clear-cut as staying in certain circles would have you think.

Thanks to everyone besides Shadow who has responded here, it's a classification and clarity issue, that holds the entire class hostage by the community.  Expectation is that a Juggernaut is some kind of tank, when really they are just a bruiser like Jax, Fiora, or Irelia without the mobility (they get higher base defensive stats and a higher base AD in trade for that mobility).

Honestly the trade off isn't so good, but the idea of hulking beasts of death lumbering toward the enemy and crushing them under boot feels so satisfying that many of us play them in spite of their weaknesses.  Would really love to see Juggernauts get a compensation for their lack of mobility that actually felt impactful.  I always suggest itemization designed for them that makes them immune to CC for the duration of an active, with severe restrictions so it would not be used by the wrong class.

There is no reason Juggernauts should not be considered tanks, but there's no reason to classify them as any other label, anyways. Tank doesn't mean anything in a game that doesn't maintain that classification, and instead splits the highly durable champions (some consider to be "tanks") into Juggernauts, Wardens, and Vanguards. It's beyond me why they even distinguished the latter two, because they both specialize in durability and utility/CC.

So, overall, I don't see it written anywhere that tanks are required to excel at utility/CC, especially in a game that has decided to circumvent the term's usage and create other classifications. They can be tanks if you want them to be, just like the rest of us can be trolls, if you want us to be. Personally, I don't care. I'll just hang out under my bridge.

Lock down means crowd control, keep in one place against their will.  It is in the first line of the definition.  Further more this definition has existed since the dawn of RPGs. . .    it's not a new one that has been invented.  If you choose not to see truth in straight foward words, that is your choice, but your persistence on believing Juggernauts are tanks is just flat wrong, they are clearly in the fighter class of champions and NOT in the tank classifications.  Durable =/= Tank.

Keep it simple, if it deals tons of damage, it's not a tank.  If it locks you down and  you die because you can't escape because you are CC'd then it's a tank.

First off, Fighter is the old classification, not the "grouping" of other groups. Now we have Divers, Skirmishers, Assassins, and Juggies, and you can do what you want to group them up, it's got nothing to do with how they line up similarly, as all of these classes do things differently. It's inherent. Otherwise they wouldn't bother distinguishing between Divers and Skirmishers, either.

Second, what's lock down got to do with anything? Tanks were never the lockdown class. They might block, or taunt, or somehow put themselves in the front of it, but there's one thing that tanks never did that Riot let them do; THEY LET THEM STUN! Stunning is **not** a tank thing! You're supposed to soak damage, not prevent damage from being dealt altogether. Tanks in LoL are, frankly, a disgrace to the name of tank. They have to be with the mobility they gave everything else, but still, *most of these guys friggin' stun*. It blows my mind.

So, overall, CC is not part of the term tank, never was. LoL peeps keep injecting it because we're so used to Garen being useless until reclassified, and Darius being unbeatable until reclassified, but in reality, *these guys can tank without the CC*. It's possible, guys, believe it.

/rant.

The only notable differences is that a tank requires other champions to deal the damage, but the juggernaut doesn't.
